--- Mitchell Timin <zenguyuno@...> wrote:
> Let me be the first to disagree with you.  I expect
> many others will also disagree.  

Well, you'd pretty much be out of step with most
modern biologists, then.

Here's an interesting short essay on the definition of
evolution:

http://www.talkorigins.org/faqs/evolution-definition.html

And if you pick up just about any biology text that
talks about evolution and it will define it most
likely as genetic change in a population over time.

> Nevertheless, evolution as a
> scientific theory includes the idea of selection. 

Selection is just one type of evolutionary pressure,
and of course there are different types of
selection--natural, artificial, and sexual.

Genetic drift is also a very important factor in
evolution, and by itself can cause a population to
evolve.  

Of course, biological populations in the real world
are never going to be subject to genetic drift as the
only evolutionary pressure.  But we *can* subject our
ANN populations solely to genetic drift as the only
evolutionary pressure.  And if we did so, they would
still evolve--that is, they would change genetically
over time.

In using NEAT, there would only be a trend toward
complexification (since NEAT only has additive
mutations).  So even if you only used random
selection, you would end up with larger, more complex
individuals at the end of your run.  They may not be
able to *do* anything meaningful, but they would still
be significantly different from their ancestors.

You may not like to think of this as evolution, but
among biologists, strictly speaking, it is.

Derek
